titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the William R. Pierce Family Photographs 1933-1979
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Mark Fritch

publicationstmt.publisher: Maureen and Mike Mansfield Library, The University of Montana--Missoula

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid encoded by Donna McCrea 2019
profiledesc.descrules: Finding aid based on DACS ( Describing Archives: A Content Standard) 2nd edition.

repository.corpname: University of Montana, Mansfield Library, Archives and Special Collections

did.unittitle: William R. Pierce Photographs
did.abstract: The photographs in the William R. Pierce collection cover a variety of subjects in Western Montana and Northern Idaho from the 1930s-1970s. Most notable are the images of Fort Missoula, Montana while it was serving as an internment camp during World War II and images of the aftermath of the 1949 Mann Gulch Fire.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: William R. Pierce was born August 13, 1915 in Topeka, Kansas. He earned a bachelor's degree in Forestry at the University of Washington and then worked as a "gandy dancer" (section hand) for the Santa Fe Railway. From there he joined the Border Patrol and worked in New Mexico before being transferred to the internment camp at Fort Missoula, Montana. He then enlisted with the Navy. Pierce earned a Master's Degree in Forest Management from Yale University in 1947. He was hired by the United States Forest Service as a district ranger at Orofino, Idaho then moved on to Thompson Falls and Noxon, Montana. Pierce earned a Ph.D. in Forest Management from the University of Washington in 1958. He taught Forestry at the University of Montana in Missoula from 1955 until he retired in 1981.
William Pierce married Joann Geddes Randall in 1943 and they had two children, Patricia (1944) and John (1948). He died on October 9, 1996 in Gig Harbor, Washington.

scopecontent.p: This collection contains photographic slides, negatives and prints taken primarily by William R. Pierce, although images from the 1930s were likely taken by another family member. Included are images of Fort Missoula, Thompson Falls, Noxon, and Missoula, Montana. Also included are many images of Montana's Cabinet National Forest back country, several of the 1949 Mann Gulch Fire, and photos of the Pierce family and recreation around western Montana and Idaho. The majority of images in the collection were described by William Pierce or his son John.
The collection also includes a heart-shaped rock carved by a Japanese internee at Fort Missoula and given to William Pierce.

arrangement.p: The materials in this collection have been arranged into four series by format.
Series II: Photograph Album, 1933-1938 and undated, 0.5 linear feet
Series III: Prints, 1942-1960 and undated, 0.4 linear feet
Series IV: Artifact, circa 1941-1944, 0.1 linear foot

accessrestrict.p: Researchers must use collection in accordance with the policies of Archives and Special Collections, the Maureen and Mike Mansfield Library, and The University of Montana-Missoula.

userestrict.p: Researchers are responsible for using in accordance with 17 U.S.C. and any other applicable statutes. Non-exclusive copyright to the images in this collection is held by the University of Montana.

prefercite.p: William R. Pierce Photographs, Archives and Special Collections, Maureen and Mike Mansfield Library, The University of Montana-Missoula.

custodhist.p: These images transferred from William R. Pierce to his son, John, who donated them to the UM Archives in several accessions.

processinfo.p: During processing, slides were placed in sleeves but retained in their original order. Prints were placed in folders by subject, generally reflecting the way the creator or donor described and organized the items. In some cases the description is written on the item, in other cases the group of materials was described.
Unidentified images have not been listed in the collection's content list.

controlaccess.p: This collection is indexed under the following headings in the online catalog. Researchers desiring materials about related topics, persons, or places should search the catalog using these headings.

scopecontent.p: This series consists of a single heart-shaped rock sculpted for William Pierce by Japanese internees held at the Fort Missoula Alien Detention Camp during World War II.
